snippet: Analyzing the DNA of dangerous butterflies who copy other unpalatable species, scientists have found that some shared color-controlling genes, signaling past interbreeding.
abstract: Researchers have found that butterflies in South and Central America have developed similar wing patterns both by evolving them independently and by interbreeding and exchanging color-controlling genes; ability to mimic markings of other butterflies, particularly those poisonous to predators, confers evolutionary advantage.
lead_paragraph: Analyzing the DNA of dangerous butterflies who copy other unpalatable species, scientists have found that some shared color-controlling genes, signaling past interbreeding.

headline.seo: Solving the Puzzles of Mimicry in Nature
headline.main: Solving the Puzzles of Mimicry in Nature
headline.print_headline: Solving the Puzzles of Mimicry in Nature
